readings: Commissioner Lin's Letter to Queen Victoria

readingAnalyses.title: Commissioner Lin's Letter to Queen Victoria
readingAnalyses.author: Lin Zexu (林則徐)
readingAnalyses.summary:
Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria stands as one of the most remarkable diplomatic documents of the 19th century—remarkable both for its moral clarity and its ultimate futility. The Qing commissioner, charged with ending the opium trade, appeals to universal principles of justice, reciprocity, and humane governance. He notes that Britain itself forbids opium domestically, asking pointedly: 'Where is your conscience?' if you sell abroad what you prohibit at home.

Lin's argument is sophisticated: he acknowledges the mutual benefits of legal trade, offers to continue commercial relations, and appeals to Victoria's reputation as an enlightened monarch. The letter reveals that Qing officials understood international commerce and could frame arguments in terms Westerners might appreciate. This wasn't a 'backward' empire failing to comprehend the modern world—it was a principled stance against drug trafficking dressed in free trade rhetoric.

Yet the letter never reached Victoria. British merchants and officials intercepted it, dismissed it, and chose war instead. The contrast between Lin's measured appeal to reason and Britain's gunboat response reveals the brutal reality of 19th-century international relations: moral arguments meant nothing without the power to enforce them.

keyQuotes.quote: Let us ask, where is your conscience? I have heard that the smoking of opium is very strictly forbidden by your country; that is because the harm caused by opium is clearly understood.
Since it is not permitted to do harm to your own country, then even less should you let it be passed on to the harm of other countries.
Our celestial dynasty rules over and supervises the myriad states... There is no country that does not desire to come to China to trade.
We have heard that in your honorable barbarian country the weights and measures are fair, that trade is equitable, and that a good reputation is valued.

thematicExamples: Lin's appeal to universal moral principles - arguing that drug trafficking violates basic ethics regardless of cultural differences
The distinction between legal trade (which Lin supports) and illegal drug trafficking (which he opposes)
Lin's acknowledgment of British commercial interests while insisting on Chinese sovereignty
The use of Confucian 'all under heaven' rhetoric combined with practical trade proposals
realLifeConnections: Contemporary debates about fentanyl trafficking from China to the US - the shoes are now on the other feet
International drug policy negotiations still grapple with balancing trade, sovereignty, and public health
The gap between moral arguments and political power remains relevant in international relations
Corporate responsibility debates - should companies be held accountable for harm their products cause abroad?

readingAnalyses.title: Treaty of Nanjing
readingAnalyses.author: British and Qing negotiators
readingAnalyses.summary:
The Treaty of Nanjing (1842) established the template for 'unequal treaties' that would define China's international relations for a century. Its provisions were devastating: Hong Kong ceded 'in perpetuity,' five ports opened to British trade and residence, $21 million in indemnities (including compensation for destroyed opium!), extraterritoriality for British subjects, and 'most favored nation' status ensuring Britain would receive any concessions China made to others.

The treaty's language reveals the power asymmetry: China 'agrees' and 'cedes' while Britain 'receives' and 'enjoys.' Yet the document also shows Qing officials trying to preserve face—referring to the payments as 'necessary expenses' rather than reparations, maintaining formal equality in diplomatic language even as substance was humiliating.

Crucially, the treaty said nothing about opium. Britain achieved its commercial goals without formally legalizing the drug trade that caused the war. This allowed British officials to claim they fought for 'free trade' rather than narcotics—a moral laundering that shaped how the West would remember the conflict.

keyQuotes.quote: His Majesty the Emperor of China cedes to Her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain, etc., the Island of Hongkong, to be possessed in perpetuity.
The Emperor of China agrees to pay the sum of Six Millions of Dollars as the value of Opium which was delivered up at Canton.
The Cities and Towns of Canton, Amoy, Foochowfoo, Ningpo, and Shanghai shall be thrown open to British Subjects.
British subjects... shall be allowed to reside for the purpose of carrying on their Mercantile pursuits, without molestation or restraint.

thematicExamples: Indemnity for destroyed opium - China forced to pay compensation for drugs it confiscated
Hong Kong cession - territorial loss that would last 155 years
Extraterritoriality - British subjects beyond Chinese law, implying Chinese legal system was inferior
Most favored nation clause - ensuring Britain automatically received any concessions China made to others
realLifeConnections: Hong Kong's 1997 return was explicitly framed as ending 'national humiliation' that began with this treaty
Contemporary Chinese suspicion of Western 'rules-based order' rooted in memory of imposed treaties
Debates about extraterritoriality continue - military base agreements, diplomatic immunity, corporate legal jurisdiction
Trade agreements today still use 'most favored nation' language, though with different implications

overallSynthesis:
These two documents—Lin's unanswered letter and the Treaty of Nanjing—crystallize the tragedy of 19th-century imperialism. Lin made a compelling moral argument that was simply ignored; Britain made war and imposed terms that served its interests. The contrast reveals that international relations in this era operated on power, not principle.

Yet the readings also complicate simple narratives. Lin's letter shows Qing China was not 'closed' to the world or incapable of diplomatic engagement—it was making sophisticated arguments within a framework it understood but couldn't enforce. The Treaty of Nanjing shows how 'free trade' rhetoric disguised what was essentially a drug cartel operating with state military backing.

For the course's larger framework, these readings mark the moment when Frank's 'Asian-centered' world economy definitively shifted. Qianlong could dismiss Macartney in 1793 because Qing power was real; fifty years later, that power had eroded enough that Britain could impose its will by force. The question isn't whether this was morally wrong (it clearly was) but what combination of factors—internal and external—had changed the balance of power so dramatically.
executiveSummary:
The First Opium War (1839-1842) marks a turning point in Chinese and world history. Commissioner Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria—earnest, logical, appealing to morality and mutual benefit—received no response. Instead, Britain sent gunboats. The resulting Treaty of Nanjing forced China to cede Hong Kong, open five 'treaty ports,' pay indemnities, and grant extraterritoriality (legal immunity) to British subjects.

This began what Chinese call the 'century of humiliation' (百年國恥)—a series of defeats and unequal treaties that shaped Chinese nationalism for generations. But the readings invite critical analysis: Lin's letter reveals sophisticated Qing understanding of international trade; the Treaty of Nanjing shows how 'free trade' was imposed at gunpoint. The moral clarity of 'China was right, Britain was wrong' coexists with harder questions about why China was militarily vulnerable and how it might have responded differently.

keyQuestions.question: Was the Opium War about 'free trade' or drug trafficking?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Britain framed it as opening trade; China saw it as defending against poison. Consider: Would we accept 'free trade' arguments for drug cartels today? But also: What alternatives did Britain have for solving trade deficit?

keyQuestions.question: Why did China lose, and what does this tell us about comparative military strength?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: British naval and artillery superiority was decisive. But why was Qing military so weak? Internal focus, financial constraints, technological gap. Connect to Frank's argument: Was this the moment the 'Great Divergence' became visible?

keyQuestions.question: How does the 'century of humiliation' narrative shape Chinese foreign policy today?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Hong Kong's return in 1997 was explicitly framed as ending humiliation. Taiwan, South China Sea, resistance to 'interference'—all connect to this historical memory. Is this narrative productive or problematic?

timeline.event: Lin Zexu destroys opium at Canton; writes letter to Victoria
Hong Kong returned to China—'humiliation' officially ended

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 6 showed Qianlong confidently rejecting British demands. Just 50 years later, China was forced to accept worse terms at gunpoint. What changed?
connections.toNext: Plate 11 examines Japan's similar encounter with Western pressure—but with very different outcomes. Why did Japan avoid 'unequal treaties' longer?
connections.broaderThemes: The Opium War initiated a fundamental reordering of East Asia's relationship with the West. Every subsequent reform movement—Self-Strengthening, Meiji, etc.—responded to this shock.

nextPreview.preview: Commodore Perry's 'Black Ships' arrived in Japan in 1853, demanding the same 'opening' that Britain had forced on China. How did Japan respond differently?

teachingNotes: Read Lin Zexu's letter aloud—it's eloquent and makes a compelling moral argument. Then discuss why it 'failed.'
The Treaty of Nanjing is short—have students identify specific provisions and discuss their implications.
Avoid simplistic 'China victim, West villain' framing while acknowledging real moral asymmetry.
Connect to contemporary drug policy debates—how do nations respond to drug crises?
Show a map of treaty ports and areas of foreign control—visualize what 'unequal treaties' meant spatially.
